word.Notes: This can be used as, but is not limited to, the infinitive form of a verb. For instance, "bok (age)" --> "boka (to age)". "-ha" is used when a word ends with a vowel. Also as a contraction with "wah," "boha" "fly to."
Meaning "with" or "having" something. "Sulvekaal" (comfortable) literally means something "with comfort" or that "has comfort".

Used to form present perfect tense and past participles. "Zu'u krifaan," "I have fought." "Zu'u mindokaan," "I have known." "Viikaan paal," "a defeated foe." When a word ends with "ah," becomes "Mahlaan" or "Grahlaan."

word.Definition: ness, forms a noun from an adjective
word.Notes: From "Krasaar," "sickness." See also "-om," an equivalent suffix.

word.Definition: Creates an noun from a verb, see notes.
word.Notes: Creates a noun from a verb meaning "one or that which is [verb]. A defendee (bildaat) is one who is defended (bildaan) or subject to defend (bild), a burden (Brudaat) is that which is carried or bared. Edited from "-aht."

Equivalent to the English "-ship" that transforms a noun or verb into a noun of higher meaning. "Dein" is used if the letter "D" is absent from the last syllable of the word, "-ein" if it contains a "D".

To turn a word into an origin, to describe where something came from, or its type.
-en for non vowel ending words, and -ren for words that end in vowel sounds.
E.g. Bron -> Bronen (Nord -> Nordic)
Dovah -> Dovahren (Dragon -> Draconic)

Referred to "Med" ("Like, Similar to"). Used to form an adjective as well as noun. It is equivalent to "-oid" or "-morph/-morphic". For example, "Muneyd" is "Humanoid, Antropomorph(ic)". "-meyd" is used for words that end in vowels.

Forms a noun from verbs or adjectives, as in "Wanderer" from "Wander", "Wunduniik". If the word ends in a vowel, the suffix is "-d", as in "Kriid". It can also be used to make nouns out of adjectives: "Zuruniik", "stranger", "Goraaniik", "youngster", meaning "someone who is strange", "someone who is young", etc.
Implies "will", E.g. Battle = Grah He will battle dragons. Rok grahliin dovahhe.
Meaning "possessing of" or "full of", modifies a noun to an adjective. An example is "Morokei" ("glorious"), based on "Moro" ("glory").
Used in "Geinmaar" and "Nimaar" to refer to the reflexive self. Used in "Briinahmaar" to form the word "sisterhood." Used in "Deinmaar" to form "keeper."

word.Definition: "-tion", used turn a verb into a noun
word.Notes:
Like -tion or -ment in English.
E.g. Imagine -> Imagination
"-end" is used in cases where "-nd" doesn't. If the word ends with a "d", "-ak" is used instead.
Indicates state or condition.
Used to turn certain verbs into negative forms, i.e. an English example would be "Isn't", "Can't", "Won't". Very rarely used.

word.Definition: turns verbs into nouns, see notes
word.Notes: This suffix makes nouns from verbs with the meaning of "something one ___ with", ex. "Pelniir", the word for "pen" or "quill", means "something one writes with".
Turns an adjective into a noun, "Vulom" = "Darkness". Edited to "-om" from "-ah"/"-rah" to match canon words.

word.Definition: changes a verb to noun, see notes
word.Notes: Makes a noun meaning "place where one ___". "Pelorun", "Scriptorium", "a place where one writes".
Derived from "Viintaas", "shining". Used to make present participles such as "viintaas tuz", "a shining blade". Replaces the old suffix -von.
Indicates "their." May be pronounced with a slight pause.
Forms a condition noun from a verb, "Hunun" = "Heroism", "Nekovun" = "Cannibalism". "-un" is used unless the verb ends in a vowel, in which case "-lun" is used instead.

word.Definition: "-y", modifies a noun into an adjective.
word.Notes: Seen in the English "snowy", "slippery", and the Dragon "Odus" and "Motmahus". Means "having the qualities of".

word.Definition: Forms an adjective from a noun.
word.Notes: Means "of, like, or pertaining to" something, "Zooruv" - "Legendary", "of/pertaining to legend". "-nuv" if the noun ends in a vowel. Edited from "-iil / -riil" to avoid conflict with canon possessive suffix.
To be used with words that end with "n".
"Aad" with the suffix "-iik", forms equivalent to "-er".
A compound of "Aak" and "Fus", "guided force". Co-authored by Numinex.
From "Aak", "guide". Noun and a verb. Edited from "Aaktir."
Derived from "Aak" and "Su", "guided air" (on the analogy of "Aakfus" - "Sneeze").
The articles "a"/"an" and "the" are rarely used in the Dragon Language.
A compound of Aaverin(Chemical) and Mindaas(Science).

word.Definition: Chemist, a person who studies chemistry

word.Notes: A combination of "Aav" (Join) and "Laas" (Life). Can be used as the verb "to wed", or the noun "wedding".
Lit. "joined essence of sorrow". Edited from "Aavriiso."
"Aaz" with the suffix "-aal", "with or having mercy".
Edited from "Hutok." Portmanteau of "Ag" and "Angaar," "burning tower."
Literally "Burn(ing) Spirit". A consuming passion, usually self-destructive. See also "Frinzii" and "Yolzii".

word.Definition: Vigilant, Attentive, Aware, Alert / Vigilance, Attention, Awareness, Alertness
word.Notes: A compound of "Ah" and "Miin", "hunter eye" or "hunter-eyed."
"Ahmil" with the suffix "-aat", "someone who is hired/employed".
From "Mindok", "to know". Can also be used as a noun.
Can be used as both a noun and verb.
Can also be used as a noun. Edited from "Hiniif." Related to "Niif," "smile."
Known as H'roldan before Old Hroldan.
The Dragon name for Whiterun, meaning "Hill of the Dragons".
Edited from "Ahlag." From "Rot," "word," imposing one's word or rule.
A compound of "Ahst" and "Staad", literally "at a place".
A compound of "Ahst" and "Tiid", literally "at a time" or "at times."
Related to "Mun", "man". Can also be an adjective.
To wear clothing, or to wear with time.
Inspired from the Old English word "æwbryce".
Also can be used as a noun. Edited from "Ahqor."
Can also be used as a verb, 'to plant".

word.Definition: Grouch, Curmudgeon, someone who is bitter

word.Notes: Refers to the musical term. "Ahzid" with "dremhah", Lit. "Bitter Harmony".
Referring to the stern of a ship, rather than the adjective meaning "serious".
Edited from "Ald" to canon "Al." "Zu'u fen al," "I will destroy."
The dragon language does not have a separate name for Alik'r. The apostrophe is removed in transliteration.
"Aluntiid" with the suffix "-uv", "of or pertaining to the future". Edited from "Aluntidiil."
Based on "Arov" with the suffix "-nuv", meaning "of, like, or pertaining to herbs". Edited from "Aroniil."
"Aros" with the suffix "-end", "the act of arriving".
Ath + end, the act of despairing.

word.Definition: Advance, Advancement, Proceed, Progress, move forward

word.Notes: The dragon language does not have a separate name for Atmora.
From Atum, "less", to be below or lower than something.

word.Definition: Schadenfreude, Sadism, joy from the suffering of others or inflicting suffering

word.Notes: From "Avok", "above", to be above or higher than something.
"Akovtum lok ahrk gol", "sky above and earth below".
Edited from "Laar" to avoid conflict with possible canon word "Laar".
Derived from "Baar", "clear", being clear or full of clearness. Edited from "Baarkei".
Alternative spelling of "Balaan." "Balaan" should normally be used.
Lit. means "worthy (of) focus/attention". Can also be used as a noun.
Edited from "Grent" to avoid closeness with canon "Krent." From "Bahlok," "hunger."
Based on "balsam" which doesn't differ in Old English, Swedish and Danish.
Both a noun and a verb. Based on "Bal", "worth". Edited froom "Bahlaas."
From the words "Eyvir" meaning "Well" and "Bahd" meaning "Manner".
"Bel" with the suffix "-iik", a practitioner of the Conjuration school.
From "Beyl", "cup", a repairer of barrels and casks.
Can also be used as an adjective.
"Beznan" with suffix "-eyd" that which resembles an ellipse/oval.

word.Definition: Lazurite, the blue stone lapis lazuli
word.Notes: From the words "Bii" meaning "Blue" and "Vild" meaning "Rock".
Can also be a noun. Edited from "Olv."
"Birgah" with the suffix "-niir," "that which is supplied or provided."
From "Bex", "to open". Pronounced with a short "i".
From "Bo," "move," and "Dein," "guard." The verb "to patrol" and the noun "patrol/vigil."
Based on Bidung (Old English, lit. "abode"). Edited from "Bodein."

word.Definition: Beam, Ray, a beam or ray of light
word.Notes: "Flowing light", used to describe a beam of light rather than a physical beam. A noun only. Edited from "Bohaan".
An alteration of "Bolog", akin to "Qahnaarin" from "Qahnaar".

word.Definition: Swoop, Sweep, esp. referring to flight
Father, also used by dragons to refer to Akatosh

word.Notes: Lit. "Father-break", styled after "Tiid-Ahraan", "time-wound". Reference to Akatosh, the father of dragons and god of time.
Pronounced "bore-ode". From Bord: table, Rohd: wheel.
Bord: table, Rod: wheel, Don: to cover.

word.Definition: Store, Stall, Booth, Boutique, any small shop

word.Notes: Edited from "Novul." Related to "Bo," "to flow." Can be used as a noun or adjective.
Based on the Norwegian word for refugee, "flyktning", and "Bovul", "to flee".
A compound of "Bo" and "Zeim", it literally means "Flow or move through".
From "Bovul". Can also be used as a verb.
The bow of a ship, rather than the verb "to bow".
The deck of a ship, as opposed to a deck of cards.
Based on Old English "bern" and the word "Hofkiin", "home".
Inspired by the dovahzhul words for beautiful and metal: brit and gelt.
"Brodaan" with the suffix "-uv," "of or pertaining to a tribe."
Inspired from the Old English word "abbodrice".
A city street, not used to mean "path" or "road".
Specifically Jarl - not just any king. Literally "nord king".
Former capitol of Skyrim and center of the Dragon Cult. Means "North Kingdom."
Edited from "Brod" to "Brot" to avoid conflict with the canon word "Brod".
From "Ag" and "Brot." Refers to bread, not a salutation or a verb meaning "to toast."
"Brud" with the suffix "-aat," "that which is carried/bared."
From "brud" meaning "to carry" and "mun" meaning "man". Together they literally mean "carryman".
Edited from "Burzah" to avoid a homonym with the word for "puzzle".
Noun and adjective; can refer to the shape, a thing in that shape, or to describe something that is that shape.
Can also be used as a verb, "to shape / to form".
Derived from Old Norse "bord". Can also be used as a verb.

word.Definition: Clang, Clash, Clamor, the sound of metal
Retaliate, Retaliation, Reprisal, to retaliate against
word.Notes: Lit. means "return-strike". "Mu daalnos niin" = "We retaliate against them".
Edited from the incorrect "Daanii", the "-ii" is actually a possessive suffix.
Can be also used as a verb.
Changed from "Do" which is "of" to "Da" for more variety of the words.

word.Definition: Scrap, to throw away or aside

word.Notes: Taken from the word "Dalk," meaning "knife," in "the old northern tongue." Described in The Infernal City by Greg Keyes.
Derived of the word Kel (which means Elder Scroll). It refers to a book or a regular scroll, any form of writing.
Derived from the words Dii and Lok, in original Dov-language, it literally means My-Sky. For Joor, it is equivalent to 'territory'.
"Deyto" with the suffix "-niir", "something your bury with".
From "Deyto," "to bury." Also a noun, "a burrow or tunnel." Edited from "Osgor."
Lit. "someone or something that is mysterious, cryptic".

word.Definition: Soda, Pop, cola or any type of carbonated drink

word.Notes: Derived from "Diist" and "Staak", it literally means "First inhabitant".
"Diist" with the suffix "-iik", "someone who is the first"
Derived from Old Norse. The verb "to dispute or argue," and the noun "dispute/argument."
Composed of the words Dil and Fahliil, it literally means Deep-Elves. Edited from "Molfahliil".
Derived from the words Dez, Orin and Deorf (Old English, lit. "problem).
This word is used more commonly in sentence structure, where "Se" is used most often to make compound words.
Can be used as a noun or adjective, but not a verb ("to iron" clothes, or "to iron out" something).
Can be a noun or a verb. Literally, "iron-wither".
As in train track. lit. means "train path" or metaphorically "train wind."
Based on the Old English word "dollic".
Related to "Ronth", "vehicle". Can also be used as a verb, "to truck or pull something along".
From "Raan". Can also be used as a verb.
The comma is in place to give you a pause in pronunciation.
"Dostoz" with the suffix "-uv", "like a fiend". Edited from "Dostoziil."
See non-canon "zey". First person subject/accusative pronoun, generally used in a canon-only setting.

Composed of the words Dovah and Miin, it literally means Dragon-Eye, bit it refers to the crimson gemstones that mortalkind call ruby - or at times, dragons-eye. The latter refers to the fire, Yol, that dragons, Dov, can create.
Is expressed as two words in-game, "Dovah Sos." See also "Sossedov."
The name of the language itself, from "Dovah" and "Zul", the "Dragon-Voice".
The name for a speaker of Dovahzul.
Edited from "Dahn" to avoid homophone with canon "Daan."
Refers to second in time, rather than the number.
Related to "Dreh," "to do." Both the noun "device" and the verb "to devise."
A happening of some sort. Accidental or purposeful.
From "Drem", "peace", and "Met", "match". Can also be used as a verb. Not to be confused for "to compliment".
"Dren" and suffix "-aal", literally "with or having action."
"Dreh" with the suffix "-niir", meaning "that which someone does something with".
From "Dren" and "Paal," lit. "the acts of a foe."
The Dov-word for the Dreugh, a race of sapient watercreatures that are well known throughout Nirn.
As in "a hearty stew". Inspired by Old Norse "drjúgr" ("ample").

word.Definition: Engage, to partake or join with something

word.Notes: From "Driin" with the suffix "-uv." Edited from "Driniil."
Based on "Dreh", "to do". Someone who has active influence in something.
Based loosely on "Dreh", "to do". Can be either the noun "result/effect" or the verb "to result in or affect".
From the Gaelic word 'Druim' meaning ridge.

word.Definition: Bring/Brought, also to cause, usher, or make happen

word.Notes: From "Kiin", something that will make you "unborn".
Lit. "crown leaf" Refers to the cannabis plant and all its derivatives, including the seeds, fibers, and drug.
Inspired by Norwegian "deilig" and "Du", "devour". Edited from non-canon "Liig".
Means "to succeed or inherit", as opposed to "Prunt" which is the antonym of "fail". Derived from "Du'ul" and "Mah", means "crown-fall".
"Dulsos" with the suffix "-aal", "having royal blood". Alternatively, "crown-bleeding". Edited from "Freiziil".
From a combination of "Du," "devour," "Nah," "fury," and the suffix "-kei."
The adjective "to be cursed", not the simple past tense of "to curse".

word.Definition: Forswear, Foreswear, Disavow, Renounce, Recant, Abjure

word.Notes: Can also be a noun. Edited from "Dufrah."
Derived from the composition of the two words Dwiirok and Siinda, it means Inscription rather than Carving, thought it could be both. Plural is Dwiisindarre.
Composed of the words Dwin and Aar, it literally means Steel-Servant and directly refers to all and any 'living' Dwemer-construct.
Comes from the Old English word "æfter".
Can also be used as a noun.

word.Definition: Fancy, Cherish, Adore, to be fond of

word.Notes: Based on "Ofan", "to give", and the prefix "En-" from "Ensosin", "bewitch".
Formed from "Gein", "one", and the prefix "En-", from "Ensosin" ("bewitch").
A combination of "Mah", with the prefix "En-" from "Ensosin".
Expanded definition to include "every" in place of non-canon words.
Compound of "Enook" and "Staad", "each-place". Edited from non-canon "Svaanveyn".
Altered from "Enst" to match the canon word.
"Evgir" with the suffix "-uv," "of or pertaining to the seasons."
From "Faad" with the suffix "-us." Edited from "Varn."
Meaning a body part; the leg, arm, wing, or tail.
Derived from Fah: for, Unt: to try. Edited from "Fahnt."
Derived from Fah: for, Unt: to try, -ak: -tion. Edited from "Fahntak."
Combination of "Faar", "Reid". Lit. means "tall", "side". Can be also used as a noun.
"Faaz" with the suffix "-aal", something that "has pain" or is "with pain".
Cannot be used as a noun, see "Fahrald".
Strictly a noun, the verb form is "Fahral".
From "Fah" and "Fos", "for what". Edited from non-canon "Vahr".
Derived from Fah: for, Unt: to try, -iik: -or. Edited from "Fahntiik."
Based off of "Usnutiid" or "Past", and "Fau" or "Fresh". Directly translates as "Fresh Time".
Derived from the composed words Feykro, Zii and Golz, its literal meaning is Forest Spirit Stone, referring to the green colour that emeralds posses and often connect it with the forest and life.
From Reid (Side). Also used as a verb
Combination of "Felniir" and the suffix "-us", adjective form of "Felniir".
Based on "Fent", "shall". Edited from "Fund" to "Fend" to avoid conflict with the existing word "Fund".
As opposed to "Dopaan" (group), this would be a "very big group". Can also be used as the verb meaning "to gather or crowd together". Edited from "Fjal."
Derived of the composition of the words Feykro and Fahliil, it means Forest-Elves and refers to the Bosmer race.
Composed of the words Feykro and Zii, it literally means Forest-Spirit.
From "Fey" and "Mah". To settle as from falling.
From Old Norse "foera". Edited from "Fjerd" and "Ferd."
"Fiilos" with the suffix "-uv", "of or pertaining to philosophy". Edited from "Fiilosiil."
A compound word of "Fil" and "Kun". Edited from "Filhaan".
Of or pertaining to the stars, not used to mean excellent or extraordinary. Edited from "Filiil."
This word and other articles like it are rarely used.
Also serves as the noun. From Ufir: respectable.

word.Definition: Inasmuch, Insomuch, According, When, While, If, as long as

word.Notes: The adjective "to be haunted", not the simple past tense of the verb "to haunt".
From "Folaas," "wrong." As an adjective, "right or correct," and as a verb, "to right/correct/remedy." Edited from "Geges" and "Ges."
From "Fo" and the suffix "-us," referring to clumsiness and numbness from being cold.
Derived from the words Dii, Fen and Scridefan (Old English, lit. "To seem").
The verb "to allude" and the noun "allusion."
Comes from the words "For," "name," and "Voth," "with." A like-named word.
A compound of "Fo" and "Tiid", something that is frozen in time.

word.Definition: Rejoice, to feel joy or great delight.

word.Notes: Derived from the words Fel, Aan and Felan (Old English, lit. "to feel").
From "Fahdon", "friend". Edited from "Fahdiin" to avoid conflict with "Diin" or "Vahdin".
A compound of "Fraan" and "Voth", "to feel with".
Composed of Frini and Laan - Eagerness and Want, Request

Composed by the words Frin, Vah and Wuld, it literally means Hot Spring Whirlwind, referring to the occasional waterspouts that erupt from geysers. It can also indicate the calmer waters around a geyser, then referring to simply the hot springs. Plural is Frinvahwuldde. Alternate form is Frinvah - Hotspring.
Literally "Heated Spirit". Uncontrollable, spontaneous, enthralling passion. See also "Agzii" and "Yolzii".
Both the noun and the verb, pertaining to meat.
Inspired by Swedish "forlata". Edited from "Foral" and related to "Aaz", "mercy". Both the verb "to forgive", and the noun "forgiveness".
Based on the word Foreloce (Old English, lit. "to look"). Edited spelling from "Fhrolok".
Both an adjective and a noun. Kin or related by blood. Expanded definition to include "kindred," "kinsman," and "relative."
General term for fruit. From Old Norse "frukt"
A modified compound of "Fruk", "fruit", and "Lom", "water", meaning "fruit-water".
Can also be used as a verb, "to message". Edited from "Dremah" to relate to "Fun," "tell."
Lit. "message-container". Can refer both to a physical box and a computer program.
Inspired from the Old English word "forsecgan".
From "Fus" and "Rot," "to make words of force." Both a verb and a noun, "to demand" and "a demand / force-words."
A compound that means "force of war".

word.Definition: Banish, Ban, Expel, Discharge, literally "Force Out".

word.Notes: Can also mean "vital" or "important". Edited from "Zrah."
From the Old English word "Gafeluc", and "Fustum", "to throw or hurl".
From Latin word 'Glannus' meaning 'Glean,' and 'Lahvraan,' 'to gather.'
Loosely based off of "Greind" or "Intellect", and "Dahrin" or "Reason".

word.Definition: Boreal, Coniferous, a boreal or coniferous forest
word.Notes: Derived from "Galik" and "Feykro", "Pine forest". Edited from "Galikro".
Means "to make or render", "Gemulaag" means "strengthen", "Gekahl" means "authorize", etc. The resulting verb is a transitive verb, which requires an object.
Based on "Bild" with the prefix "Ge-", "to make defended".
Edited from "Genovul." "Bovaal", "liquid", with the prefix "Ge-". Means "to make liquid".
Based on "Pahgein" and "Gein" with the prefix "Ge-", "to make one".
A shortening of "Gegeinend", "Gegein" with the suffix "-end".
Composed of Gein and Fahliil, it literally means One-Elf and refers to the time when the Aldmer encompassed all of the Elven-races.
Composed by the words Gein and Golslen, it is the Dov's name for the Hist, who are said to be one of the first races on Nirn and one of only two of those races to still exist.
Derived from "Geinrah" with the suffix "-aal", "with or having one god".
A compound of "Gein" and "Rah", "One god" (on the analogy with "Pogaanrah" - "Many gods").
Follows the same root as "zirokey" but with the number "gein."
Derived from "Gein", "Zahk" and "Key", it literally means "One-horned horse".
"Jahrii" with the prefix "Ge-", "to make full". Edited from "Gejahr."
Derived from "Krin", with the prefix "Ge-", "to make courageous".
Can also be used as a verb.
"Laag" with the prefix "Ge-", "to make sleep", "to make tired".
From "Lok", "to make high" or "put in the sky." Edited from "Gekriis."
From "Gelok" with the suffix "-aat," "that which is elevated."
Pertaining to Chemistry. "Gelt" with the suffix "-eyd."
"Lum" with the prefix "Ge-." The verb meaning "to lower", rather than the adjective "more low than." Edited from "Gekrinil."
Based on "Malingraan", "to make short in length". Edited from "Gemalingren."
"Mindok" with the prefix "Ge-", literally "to make known".
"Moro" with the prefix "Ge-", "to make glory of".
Edited from "Kirnd" and "Ligendaal." From "Genaz", "pleasure," "with or having pleasure."
From "onik" with the prefix "Ge-", "to make wise".
"Saak" with the prefix "Ge-", "to make large or big".
Prefix "ge-" and "saavir". Literally, "make-rich". Refers to quality rather than wealth.
Derived from "Sahlo", "weak". Implies the taking away of strength, versus "Imzalo" which implies sickness or illness.
"Tiraaz" with the prefix "Ge-", "to make sad". Corrected from "Getiraaz".
Any large, fortified, elevated place, larger than a fort or keep.
From "Volz", "to make worse". Edited from "Gevol" to avoid conflict with the canon "Vol".
From "Vozahlaas" with the prefix "Ge-," "to make immortal."
"Yol", "fire", with the prefix "Ge-", literally "to make on fire".
"Zeydo" with the prefix "Ge-", literally "make just". An "h" was added to facilitate verb suffixes.
"Gluus" with the suffix "-kei", literally, "to be full of luck or fortune".
Also verb form, "to pause". Edited from "Hilv."

word.Definition: Catacomb, Crypt, any underground place of burial
word.Notes: Derived from Golz and Graad together to make "stone grave".
Gol: earth, Klov: head, refers to a geographic pole.
Compound meaning "earth-fall", to "fall to earth". Is the verb "to land" and also the noun "landfall".
Derived from "Gol" and "Lom" with the suffix "-en", it literally means "from earth and water"
Based on "Golrosik" with the suffix "-uv". Edited from "Vuruniil."

Derived from the composite-word Golslengolz, it means Treeblood Stone and refers to the fossil-gemstone Amber, as it's usually made from tree-sap. Given the fact that Alduin and his Dov are directly created by Lorhkan and Akatosh, they would undoubtingly know of the precise origins of amberstones.
A compound of "Gol" and "Tef" with the suffix "-end"

Composed by the words Golz and Aar, it literally means Stone-Servant or Stone-Slave. Though the concept is hardly known in Tamriel itself, it can also apply to the automatons of the Dwemer, as they come from the very stones around the dwemer cities, though of course certain processes are found in between the basic material and the finished product. Plural is Golzaarre.
Compound meaning "Stone of the West". Edited from "Golzewelkand."
From "Golz" and "Okaaz", roughly "stone of the sea".
"Goraan" with the suffix "-iik", literally "someone who is young".
Derived from "Test"/"Gor" and "Truth"/"Vahzen", literally "testing for the truth".
Can also be used as an adjective.
It is derived from the words Govey and Gein, Remove and one, meaning Removed One.

word.Definition: Grave, esp. that of a warrior
word.Notes: Related to "Grah," a grave, particularly of one who has died in battle.
May be used as either a noun or adjective.
From "Grah", "battle", to strike, or defeat/win against. Edited from "Grahr" and "Graht."
Pertaining to small and organized groups of soldiers. Lit. "battle-group."
Lit. "battle-ship." Any ship used for battle or war.
"Gram" with the suffix "-us", now based on the canon word for "cloud".
From the Old English word "Grene". Also related to "Slen", "flesh".
Related to "Graar", "crude", but with more of a leaning toward comedic sexuality.
Can also be used as a verb, "to doubt". Edited from "Ren."
Means "bind-voice". The verb "to sentence" as in "deliver a sentence" rather than the grammatical unit.
Pronounced "Groo-een". Can also be the verb form.
Derived from Old Norse "gruna". Also related to "Gruth", "betrayal". Can be used as a noun.

word.Definition: Telescope, Spyglass, Binoculars, any instrument used to see further

word.Notes: A compound of "Haad" and "Voh" with the suffix "-iik", it literally means "who denies his oath". Particularly can be used for native-born population of the Reach
Lit. "hand-egg", referring to the shape of the ball being held in the hand.
Derived from "Haal" and "Jusk", it literally means "hand claw".
A portmanteau of both "Hadrim" and "Tiid", and means "Mind-Time", as in the time you spend alone with your mind i.e. meditate.
Synonyms with "Hahdrim", and it seems to be the root of it.
Edited from "Hasiiv." Related to "Hah" and "Golt," "grounded in the mind."
From "Hah," "mind," something false or unreal rooted in the mind.
The noun or the verb. Lit. "mind-bend."
Slightly inspired by the Norwegian word for mood, humør. From "Hah," "mind." Edited from "Hjumoor."
Composed of the words Hahnu and Heim, it literally means Dream-Forge and refers to the state in which one enters when having visions or hallucinations.
"Hah" with the suffix "-uv," "of or pertaining to the mind."
From "Hahsefil". One who studies the stars.
From "Hah" and "Luug," "mind of flags," the study of flags, their history, design, etc.
A compound of "Hah" and "Rah", "mind of god".
Derived from "Hah", "mind", and "Voth", "with". Can only be used as a verb.
"Haav" with the suffix "-aat", "that which is entered". Edited from "Havaht."
Speaking to a plural group rather than a singular "you", "you all". "Hi" may also be used in this way, but this invented word is specific to the plural.
A combination of "Hes", "sweet", and "Hopik", "potato". Edited from "Hespak."
Refers to the musical term. "Hez" with "dremhah", Lit "Bright Harmony."
"Hez" with "Honaat," lit. "bright sound" or "bright-sounding." Refers to sound rather than linguistics.
A combination of "Hiim" and "Jun", literally "City of Kings".
Edited from "Hiil" to avoid conflict with "Hil", "heart".

word.Definition: Ivarstead, formerly known as Hillgrund's steading

word.Notes: Amended definition to differentiate it from "Hofkiin".
Edited from "Hudaal," related to "Hindah," "favor" with the suffix "-aal."
A stupid person. Used as an insult.
Follows the same root as "zirokey" (bicycle) but with the number "hir".
Edited from "Hiriid." The verb "to imply" and the noun "implication."
"Hofkiin" with the suffix "-uv," "of or pertaining to the home."
Derived of the words "Hofkiin" and "Spaan", "house-shield." Edited from "Bodeiken" and "Bodeinspaan."
A place that is crossed. Hok plus -aat.
Conjunction of "Hok" and "Deiniik" meaning "Cross" and "Guard." The metal guard that is at the base of the sword. It is above the hilt.
Derived from the composition of the words "Hokoron" and "Zii".
"Hokzii" with the suffix "-us", demon-like. Edited from "Hokziil."
"Hon" with the suffix "-aat", "that which is heard". Edited from "Honaht."
"Honaatmul" with suffix "-uv," lit. "of or pertaining to tone."
From "Honah", "sense" with suffix "-aat," "that which is sensed." Edited from "Honand."
From "Hon", "to hear", with the suffix "-niir", "with which one hears".
"Hon" with the suffix "-uv," "of or pertaining to hearing or sound."
From "Hon" and "Lovaas," refers to a musical note. Edited from "Honfask."
Noun only. Expanded definition to include "snare."
Verb only. Expanded definition to include "Ensnare."
Based on the Norse "jotunn". Edited from "Hjot."
Edited from "Koshu'um." "Huvut" with the suffix "-aat," "that which is required."
A combination of the words "caution" and "less".
Can be both a verb, and a noun.
A compound of "Iilah" and "Kun". Edited from "Iilahaan".
Based on the word for "orc," Ogiim, assuming it is equivalent to "Orsimer."
A compound of "Iiz" and "Malur", meaning "a piece of ice".
Can also be used as a verb, "to fish".
The verb meaning "to hide", not an animal's hide.
Can also be used as a verb. Simplified "Irkbo" and "Irkbaan" into one word, both a noun and a verb.
Also used as the verb. Inspired by Icelandic "tjalda".
Derived from Jiik, Joy. Yay is an informal word that expresses triumph, approval, or encouragement.
Related to "Kriist", "to stand". Something that stands against or in the way.
Edited from "Jeer" to "Jir", as "ee" isn't used in Dovahzul.
Can be used as both a noun, "reflection", and a verb, "to reflect".
From Joriin: people, and Joor: Mortal
Related to Jor: Person, and Joor: Mortal.

word.Definition: Estuary, Inlet, Bay, the mouth of a river

word.Notes: Expanded definition to include "humanity." Means the collective "all men" or "all humans," not to be used to refer to an individual human. For this see "Mun."
From the words "Jud", "queen", and "Vulon", "night". Refers to the Daedric Prince.
From the Finnish word "Juoma" (liquor). Shortened from "Juum."
May be rarely used to refer to "light" or a "guiding light." See also "Kun."
Lit. "claw count." The noun from of "Tii."
Derived from Krelt and Kagaav, Medal and Amulet/Pendant.
Edited from "Kahr" to avoid association with "Kahriil".

word.Definition: Pang, sharp sudden pain or painful emotion

word.Notes: From "Kaazah" and "Key," lit. "tiger horse." Edited from "Ruvaarkey."
Translated to "cat of the clouds" due its spots. Edited from "Kaazsegram".
From "Kahmaar", to boast.. Literally "one who takes pride in themselves".
From "Kaliid", "fable", so great as to be from fable or myth.
Derived from "Kalul" and "Mun", it literally means "Ox-man". Plural is Kalumuz.
Can also be used as a verb, "to skin".
Differs from "Horvutah". "Horvutah" implies being lured or tricked. This means being stuck or trapped in a position without being tricked or lured into that position.

Related to "Hahkun". The Lochaber axe was a Scottish war axe that came into use around 1600. The name of the weapon derives from Lochaber, an area in the western Scottish Highlands, as the weapon was employed principally by the Scottish highlanders, who (generally without any cavalry of their own) required armament against cavalry.
Combines "kein" (war) and "joor" (mortal). Known as the First Dragon War to the Nords, the Dragons refer to it as "The War of Mortals".
"Kein" with the suffix "-us", "having the qualities of war".
An animal pelt, as opposed to the English verb "to pelt".
An animal's bark, as opposed to the bark of a tree. Also a noun.
From Old Norse "kenna" and a reversal of "Naak", "to eat". Edited from "Sahlok" to avoid confusion with the dragon "Sahloknir", "phantom sky hunter".
Derived from "Kendov" meaning warrior. Edited from "Ken" and "Kend".
"Kenlok" with the suffix "-us", "having the qualities of a circle".
A compound of "Key" and "Mun", it literally means "Horse-man". Plural is "Keymuz".
Pronounced like "care". Can also be used as a verb, "to awe or to marvel".
A young horse of either gender
Comes from words 'kiir' meaning 'child', and 'dreh' meaning 'do'. Lit. "Child-do" which loosely means "That which a child would likely do."
Refers to "Kip", "Food". Also can be used as a verb, "Digest"
Also is a verb meaning "to lay siege to"; "Nust kirgar Ahrolsedovah".
From "kliiz" and "faak";Noun and verb: means both amputation and to amputate.
"Kliizfaak" + "-aat"; can refer to both an amputee or his removed appendage
The 'r' is rolled more deeply than usual. "The feeling of sand". Can be used as a noun.

word.Definition: Dust devil, dancing devil, dust whirl, any type of small, low strength tornado

word.Notes: From Old Norse "hauss" and "Klov," "head." Edited from "Huus."
Not commonly used, often left to context.
From Norwegian for "connect". A noun and a verb.
Derived from "Kos" and "Diist", it literally means "be first". Also can be used as a noun: "Original", "Primary source".
Can be also used as an adjective.
A compound of "Ko" and "Los". To say "where is ... ", you would say "kolos ... " instead of "kolos los ... ".
A compound of "Ko" and "Mah", "in-fall", "to fall into". Doesn't need to be used with the prepositions "Ko" or "Kotin".
"Komaan" with the suffix "-aal", literally "a thing that holds decision". Edited from "Mahndaal."
From "Nos," "to strike." Also as a noun, "infliction."
"Kopraan" with the suffix "-uv," "of or pertaining to the body."
Derived from the words Kopraan and Dein, lit. "Body-Keep", as in holding a certain defensive/offensive position.

word.Definition: Glasses, Spectacles, Monocle, Spyglass, any seeing aid made of glass

word.Notes: Literally, "see like." Expresses that you share the same view as the speaker.
Derives from "Koraav", "to see". A noun only.
From "Ko," "in," denoting something that lies within. Edited from "Puulin."
Based on "Kos", an expanded meaning of "to be".
Both the noun and the verb.
The final resting place of High King Borgas, same in the Dragon Tongue as English.
The verb "kos" with the suffix "-aan". "Zu'u kosaan" = "I have been".
Portmanteau of the words Kos "Be" and Se "Of", i.e. Of Dwemer Origin.

word.Definition: Literal, Literalness, inner or true meaning

word.Notes: Is a compound of "Ko" and "Sil"; "kosil vokul," "an inner evil / an evil in the soul." For inanimate objects, use "Ko" or "Zuko."
Noun or verb. From "Mey" and "Kos," "to befool."
"Kostir" with the suffix "-uv", "of or pertaining to practice". Edited from "Kostiriil."
Derived from "Tend", "obstruct". The verb "to congest or clog" and the noun "congestion".
Lit. "in some wind / by some wind." Edited from "Kozen."
Based on "Volk" with the suffix "-niir", "something used to hold something in".
The unit of measurement rather than the physical foot. Is its own plural.
From "Kos". A trait or characteristic, rather than something that is of high quality.

word.Definition: Corruption, Virus, anything that corrupts health

word.Notes: A dragon name for Peryite, "Sick Wither Master".
Derived from the words Kras and Ahraan, lit. "Sick-Wound".
From "Kras," "sick." The adjective "vile/gross" and the verb "to disgust."
A compound of "Kras" and "Sum", it literally means "sick breathing". Can also be used as a noun.
Compound of "Kred" and "Jun," lit. "game of kings."
Composed of the words Krien and Vulon, it literally means Sun-Night.
Derived from Gelt and Kerf, metal and coin.

word.Definition: Saber, Scimitar, Cutlass, any kind of curved sword

word.Notes: From "Kren" and "Lom," to describe water breaking upon the shore.

word.Definition: Crash, crash landing, esp. from flight
Divide, Separate, Split, Division, Separation, Schism
word.Notes: From "Kren", "break". The verb "to divide" and the noun "divide / division / separation".
Taken from Kreh meaning bend and Zahkrii meaning sword.
From "Krii" and "Lom," "to kill water." The verb "Dir" would be used for "evaporate" as an intransitive verb; "the water died."

word.Definition: Slaughter, the act of killing or slaying
word.Notes: The noun from "Krii" with the suffix "-nd".

word.Definition: Archon, Magistrate, anyone in high power
word.Notes: Refers, to anyone holding a high office or power.
From "Kril," "brave." Edited from "Yin," to brave something or face something with bravery.
From "Krii," "to kill oneself." Can also be used as a verb that means "to commit suicide." Edited from "Veslaad."
Derived from Krizey: opponent. Krif: to fight; Zeymah: brother.
Derived from Kriz: to oppose. Krif: to fight, Zeymah: brother.
Derived from "Krinil" and "Ogiir", it literally means "lower leg"
Derived from "Krongrah", "victory", and the suffix from "Morokei", "glorious", based on "Moro", "glory".
Derived from "Kroson" and "Nimaar", "works itself". Mainly refers to dwemer machinery except automatons (for them word "dwinaar" is used)

word.Definition: Meddle, Pry, Interfere, Snoop, to nose

word.Notes: Derived from Krosis, sorrow, as the meaning is similar.
Taken from Krosis and Lovaas to be a song of mourning for the lost.
The word is often used in conversation as a remark, using "sorrow" to express regret, pity, or sympathy.
Is both the noun and the verb.
'Kroson' with suffix '-orun'. Literally 'Place where one works.'
Used as a verb, "to disgrace or corrupt".

word.Definition: Rightness, Birthright, ancient right or privilege

word.Notes: Related to "Vokul", which literally means "ungood". See "Pruzah" for the sense that would be used in "I'm doing good", or "good day".
Lit. "Good Face". Can also be used as a verb.
Taken from Greek. Not related to 'Kun', meaning 'light'.
Based on "Kun", "light". The adjective meaning "lit" as in "a lit candle", rather than the past tense of "to light". Edited from "Kunt."
Can also be used as a verb meaning "to interest". "Zu'u kusahlaan ko..." = "I am interested in..."
A modification of "Kusah" with the suffix "-aal", "with or having interest".
"Kuyiz" with the suffix "-aat", "that which is launched/projected".
"Kuz" with the suffix "-niir", "that which one grabs with". Means a grappling hook, not to be confused for the verb "to grapple". Edited from "Kuniir".
Can be used as either a noun or verb.
Derived from Laag, sleep. Can also be used as a noun.
Edited from "Laan". Related to "Laan", "want". The verb "to ask or to question", and the noun "question/inquiry".
"Laas" with the suffix "-uv", "of or pertaining to life". Edited from "Laasiil."
From "Lah" with the suffix "-iik", a general term for anyone who possesses the powers of Magicka.
"Lah" with the suffix "-lun" (on the analogy of "Rahlun")
Related to "Lah," "magicka." Edited from "Lahvuun." Also a noun, "Mystic."
"Lahnik" suffixed with "-aar." Can be used for general belief in something supernatural as well as for the Mysticism Magic School. Edited from "Lahvuunom."
A compound of "Lahvraan" and "Voth", "gather-with". Shortened from "Lahvraanoth."
A derived word of the composite "Lahzeymah", "magic-brother".
A compound of "Laat" and "Tiid", "lasting through time".
With "-uv", "of or pertaining to the world". Edited from "Leiniil."
Based on the Finnish word for source, lähde, and the Estonian word for source, läte.
Exit a room or building (as opposed to the generic "Geyn" (leave).
The way out of a room or building, or situation. "That which is exited".
Edited from "Kir" to avoid conflict with canon "Kiir". The adverb "please," not the verb "to please."
Derives from "Smoliin", "passion". Can be used as a noun or a verb. It doesn't require prepositions or additional helping verbs. You would simply say "Zu'u liin mok/mek".
Liis is a word for vicious hissing. It can also be used for the Dovahzul equivalent of the English haha: liisisis.
Derived from the composition of the words Lokluv and Golz, its literal meaning is Skytear Stone, referring to the colour of the gem.
Edited from "Kriis." Based on the analogy of "Tum," "down," and "Lum," "low."
Also the verb "to love." Edited from "Lokal."
Derives from "Lokaal" and the suffix "-us". Edited from "Lokalus."
From the words "Lokaal" meaning "love" and "Horvut" meaning "lure". Edited from "Lokavut."
"Lokaal" with the suffix "-in" instead of "-iik" for a gentler sound. Edited from "Lokalin."
"Lokaalvut" with the suffix "-aal" , "with or having attraction".
Composed of the two words Lok and Luv, meaning Sky and Tear/Tears. Already, rain often is seen as the crying of a certain deity.
Combined of Lokluv (Rain) and Fahin (Colour). Could also be interpreted as "Sky Tear Color".
Lokoltei with the suffix -ren denoting origin. E.g. That's Imperial -> Tol Lokolteiren. He's an Imperial -> Rok Lokolteiren.
Edited from "Kriith." "Lok" with the suffix "-om," "highness" or "skyness."
From Lok: sky, Kos: to be
A compound of "Lok", "Se" and "Staad", it literally means "sky of the place" (on the analogy of "Lokos" ("Sky being") which means "Weather").
Of or pertaining to the sky. Edited from "Lokiil."
Composed of the words Lok and Zii, it refers to the Spirits of the Sky, also known as 'angels' in certain cultures or religions.
From "Lom" and "Mah," the falling of water.
Lit. "thought-charge," "to charge with thought." Edited from "Tek."
A compound of "Lot" and "Dwinaar", referring to the Dwemer Centurions.
Derived from the words "Lot" and "Lom". Edited from "Lo'om" and "Lohom."
Derived of the words "Lot", "Muz" and "Sunvaar", it literally means "Great Men Beasts" (on the analogy of "Golsemuzaar")

word.Definition: Behemoth, Colossus, any creature of great size

word.Notes: Prima Official Skyrim Game Guide, p. 647
From "Lo," "deceive," and "Horvut," "lure." For the noun see "Horvut."
Derived from Lokluv and Feykro, it describes the wetness of the environment and the density of the trees.
Edited from "Krinil." Reverse-derived from "Lumnaar," here meaning "low peak." Possibly also related to "Tum," "down."
From the words "Brii" meaning "beauty" and "Lund" meaning "nature".
As in the natural world. Directly from Old Norse.
"Lund" with the suffix "-uv", "of or pertaining to nature". Edited from "Lundiil."
The verb "to solve" and the noun "solution".
"Luv" with the suffix "-aal," "with or having tears."

word.Definition: Cry, Weep, Mourn, to shed tears

word.Notes: "Maad" with the suffix "-us". Does not have the same connotations as the English "nutty".
derived from Old English “mægen-”; "main" as used in combination like “main road“ ('maagstrah') or “main thing“ ('maagtruk')
'maag' derived from Old English “mægen-” ("main"; used in combination), combinated with 'strah' (way/road).
The adjective meaning "resolute or determined," not the past tense of "to determine" or "to resolve."
Lit. means "cause", "terror". A person who causes terror.
Also a noun. Edited from "Miknuur." Slightly derived from "Vaat," "to swear."
Altered spelling from "Hadrimwhal", then from "Madrahl" and "Marahl."
A modification of "Mahraal" with the suffix "-aal", "with imagination". Edited from "Marahdaal."

word.Definition: Shaky, Rickety, structurally weak or likely to fall or collapse

word.Notes: From the Old English word "māwan" and also uses the word "mah" (fall).
Literally "Little book". A written letter, rather than individual letters such as "A" or "B".
A compound of "Mal" and "Lingraan", "short of length", as opposed to "Maltiid" which means "short of time". Edited from "Malingren."
Literally: "[a] little of silver", from the literal translation of "platina" from Spanish. ("little silver").
A compound of "Mal" and "Tiid", it means "short" as in a period of time, not a measure of length or height.

word.Definition: Piece, Bit, Chunk, Part, Section, Portion, Component

word.Notes: From "Veydo" and "Raak," lit. "little grass-stick" or "little weed-stick." Shortened for phonetic reasons.

word.Definition: Schooner, any type of small sailing vessel

word.Notes: Derived from the base Eurasian word for the animal.
Based on "Meyar", Literally "of or pertaining to oneself". Edited from "Mariil."
From "Maar" and "Zul," to scream, esp. in terror.
Adapted from 'meyz' and 'bein'. Means 'to become foul.'
Lit. "like-brother," referring to something that is related or equivalent.
Compound of "Med" and "Koraav," "to look like or similar to."
From "Med" and "Ven," shortened from the phrase "in a like wind."
Lit. "plan-time". Can be used as a verb.
From the Icelandic for "during," "meðan.", and related to "Laat", "last/lasting".
Derived from the pronoun ending -maar, but separated from "Maar" meaning terror. Edited from "Ma'are".

word.Definition: Single-Handed, Alone, Unaided, by oneself or on one's own
word.Notes: Also an adverb. "Meyar" with the suffix "-dein," "self-ship."
Derived from the words, self and anxious and modified to flow better.
From "Meyar" and "Ven," "self-wind" or possibly "fool's wind." Could also be used as a noun.
The "fool's dragon", referring to the dragonlings of the Iliac Bay region.
Can also be the noun, an act of spurning.
"Meyr" with the suffix "-en", "of or from ancestors".
Derived from 'mey', fool, and 'rothaar', prayer. Literally, "prayer fool."
Name of the Daedric Prince, "Fool Swear Deceive".
Lit. "fool's wind," a fool's way through an obstacle or difficulty.
Means "loyal dragon." Can only be used to refer to a dragon.
The accusative and dative case of "Mu".
"Miin" with the suffix "-uv," "of or pertaining to the eyes or eyesight."
Lit. "that which is taught", "Mind" with the suffix "-aat".
"Mindaziik" with the suffix "-ein." Refers to the studies of a scholar, not money that is granted for education.
Edited from "Yirtiilaar" to fit the canon "Mindol".

word.Definition: Teacher, Mentor, Tutor, lorekeeper, sage, secret keeper
word.Notes: Literally translates to (with a slight variation) "Know of all".

word.Definition: Ensue, Follow, Succeed, Following, Successive, Subsequent, Consequent
word.Notes: From "Mindin," "after." As a verb, to come after or follow something in time. As an adjective, something that has followed or ensued.
"Mirodah" with the suffix "-aat", "that which is sung".
Both the noun and the verb.
From "Mith," "middle." Can be used as both a noun and an adjective.
Altered from "Hil" to match canon word.
Intended to be the root of "Morah", "focus". Can also be used as an adjective.
The verb meaning "to like", not the word meaning "as" or "like".

word.Definition: Moo, Low, the sound of a cow
Supremacy, Regency, supreme or total power

word.Notes: Lit. "without strength." Also used to mean "wrong" or "false," as strength is equivalent to truth and rightness.
From "Mul", "strength", and the "Ronaaz" family of words.
Edited from "Aarthok". "Mul" and "Vos", the strength to be able.
A compound of "Mun" and "Am", "man-lion" (on the analogy of "Mungrohiik").
A compound of "Mun" and "Dilaar", "man-vulture" (on the analogy of "Mungrohiik").
"Mun" with the suffix "-eyd". Also can be used as an adjective.
A compound of "Mun" and "Hraak", "man-boar" (on the analogy of "Mungrohiik").
A compound of "Mun" and "Kodaav", "man-wolf" (on the analogy of "Mungrohiik")
A compound of "Mun" and "Krozol", "man-crocodile" (on the analogy of "Mungrohiik").
Used as in "to make happy." See "Wahl" for "make" as in "to create."
"Lein Naakin", "World Eater". Uses the same suffix as "Qahnaarin", as opposed to "-iik" because "Naakiik" was awkward to pronounce.
From "Naalein", "someone who is alone". Edited from "Enariik".
The animal, rather than a baseball or cricket bat, or the verb meaning "to bat (away)".
From "Naat" and "Niiv," "bat-ball." Cricket as in the sport, not the insect.

Based on Nahgahdinok ("necromancer"), which may be a combination of Nag (Fury) Gah (Yield) and Dinok (Death) or "Nahgah" and "Dinok". Either way, "Fury Yield" could come to mean "diviner" or "charmer" ("mancer").
Related to "Fahin", color. For the verb, see "Verilir". Edited from "Naain."

word.Definition: Vengeance, Revenge, to kill in revenge
word.Notes: Lit. "fury-slay." The noun "vengeance" and the verb "to kill in revenge."
A compound of "Nahl" and "Rii", "Living essence". Edited from "Nahlrii."
Based on "nahlon," "silent." Can also mean the noun, "someone who is mute".
A modification of the word "Nahlii" based on "Briinahmaar", "Sisterhood". Edited from "Nahlriimaar."
From "Neben". Can also be used as a noun.
Lit. "under-wing," to take beneath one's wing.
Neilaas with the suffix -end, the act of surviving.
Lit. mean 'Quick Walk'. Can also be used as an adjective.
Edited from "Niin" to "Nen" to avoid conflict with the canon "Niin".
Forming a noun from the verb "Nep" with the suffix "-end".
Derived from the words Nok and Tey.
From "Bo," "to fly or move," describing someone that is not inclined to move. Edited from "Juuboh."
Also can be used as a noun
Derived from the words Nin and Golz, lit. "stinging stone".
The possessive form of "Nii", used as an adjective but listed here as a pronoun for search reasons.
Can also be used as a verb.
Plural possessive pronoun of "Nust". Edited from "Nustu".
The precipitation rather than "to call or hail". From Niiv: ball, Iiz: ice.
"Laan" with the prefix "Ni-," "not-wanted." See also canon "Volaan," "intruder."
From "Nil", "void". Can be also a noun and a verb.
Corrected a spelling mistake, was formerly "Niimaar".
Edited from "Vofranvothok". From "Nis" and "Franvoth", "cannot be consoled".
From "Nis" and "Hind", "cannot hope". See also "Ath" and "Hindnu".
Derived from "Korah" combined with "Nis", "cannot be believed". Edited from "Vokorahtok".
"Vos" with the prefix "Ni-." The adjective "unable" and the verb "to disable/disallow/prevent."
Derived from "Nivosend", "Se" and "Vild", it literally means "Split of a rock"
A combination of the word 'Yusgri' and the prefix 'ni-'.
Means "to lie down," "to lay something down," and "to tell a falsehood."
"Lying dream". Both the verb "to hallucinate" and the noun "hallucination".
From "Nok", "to "lie," "someone who lies." Not to be confused with "Praav," "lair."
Based off of "Naan". Means "anything at all".
From "Nonvul", "noble". Edited from "Nonvulom" to avoid association with "Vulom".
Composed of the words Nonvul and Golz (Stone, countable), it defines the stones that man see as valuable or "noble".
"Noorend" with the suffix "-aal", "with or having emotion".
The verb "to blame, accuse, or charge", and the noun "blame, charge, or accusation". Lengthened to "Noraas."
Dereived from "Noraas". Can also be used as a noun.
Part of the "Cyclone" shout in Dragonborn dlc.
Lit. "striking action". In relation to "offense and defense", not "offended".
Derived from Middle High German 'notten' (move around/shake).
This is the root for the the expression of "thank you". Verb: To thank.
Can also be used as a verb, "to ready".
Reverse derived from canon word 'Vonun' meaning 'unseen'.
Edited from "Nun" to avoid conflict with semi-canon "Nun".
Lit "Bare", "Word". Can also be used as an adjective.
Composed of the words Nu and Tiid, it literally means Now-Time.
Means "To be present throughout". Related to "Nuviis".
"Oben" with the suffix "-aal", something that is "with or having expense".

Composed of the words Od and Fahliil, it literally means Snow-Elf and refers to the few pre-Falmer elfs that have not degenerated. It also refers to the entire Falmer-race pre-corruption by the Dwemer.
A denomination that refers to the Kamal-races, that live in Akaviri and were well known to the Dov, who once ruled those Dragonlands.
Expanded definition to include "get, gain, obtain, acquire."
Literally "that which is given", "Ofan" with the suffix "-aat".
"Ofun" with "lor", lit. "share-thought." Noun or a verb.
General term for a berry, the small fruit. Directly from Latvian.
From Ogiim and Nor (Orc and Land/Province).
Taken from Okaaz (primary) meaning sea and Himdah (quaternary) meaning home.
Variation of the word "Okaaz" which means sea.

word.Definition: Mate, Partner, Boyfriend, Girlfriend, Companion, any romantic partner

word.Notes: A modification of "Hah" with the prefix "Or-".
"Balaan" with the prefix "Or-", "worthy again". Edited from "Orbahlaan."
"Bex" with the prefix "Or", to open again.
"Frolok" with the prefix "Or-". Can be used as both a noun and verb.
"Komiin" with the prefix "Or-" To design again
"Lahney" with the prefix "Or-," to live again.
From "Yos" with prefix "Or-". Can also be used as a noun.
"Ozinvey" and "Haal", meaning "ivory hand" in reference to older pianos having ivory keys.
Derived from "Paagol" (walk) and the Swedish word "Lufsa" (shamble). A way of walking, not as in shuffling of cards.
Means "fair" as in "just," and "fair" as in "pleasant" or "beautiful."
From "Pah" and "Leinuv", "pertaining to all the world". Edited from "Pahleiniil."
"Pahlok" with the suffix "-aal", "with or having arrogance".
"Pahsu" with the suffix "-aal", "with or having confidence". Edited from "Edrahaal."
A compound formed from "Pah", "all", and "Voth", "with". Literally, "allwith".
A compound of "Pah" and "Vahl" with teh suffix "-iik", it literally means "All-Creator". A mysterious deity revered as the wellspring of creation by Ancient Atmorans and modern Skaal.
Taken from the Icelandic word for "platform", "pallur."

word.Definition: Pen, Pencil, Quill, any writing utensil
word.Notes: "Pel" with the suffix "-niir", "something one writes with".
A compound of "Pel" and "Noot", it literally means "writing skill"
"Pel" with the suffix "-orun", "a place of writing".
Lit. means "to write a point," or "written point."
Both the noun "punishment" and the verb "to punish".
Refers to a grassland or field, rather than an adjective describing something that is plain or simple.

word.Definition: Vessel, Glass, Jug, Horn, Mug, anything that one drinks from
word.Notes: "Piin" with the suffix "-niir", "something one drinks with".
Edited and expanded from "Diskutirok". A phrase that means "many-faced".
Based on words: Pogaan(Many) and Ogiir(Leg).
Derived from "Pogaanrah" with the suffix "-aal". Means "with or having many gods".
A compound of "Pogaan" and "Rah", it literally means "Many gods".
The measurement of weight, rather than the verb "to pound" or the money.
A slightly shortened form of 'praadniir piin', lit. "the awakening drink".
From "Praak" and "Ronaaz," lit. "slithering arrow." Refers to the cursor or mouse of a computer.
Expanded definition to include "seat." The verb "to sit or seat," and the noun "seat."
Edited from "Grim" to relate to canon "Praan".
Can also be used as a verb.
I changed the spelling a bit so it doesn't get confused with the suffix "-rah".
Edited from "Priivu'um." Possibly related to "Vum," "beard," as a word of authority.
Can be noun or adjective. Related to "Pruzah", "good".
"Foretelling Wind", to foreshadow or hint at something. Can be a noun or a verb.
Edited from "Kunus." From "Kuz" with "Pro-" as in "Prodah."
Derived from "pruzaan", "best". Can be used as an adjective.
Opposite of Funt: to fail. Derived from Unt: to try, Pruzah, good.
"Pruvos" with the suffix "-aal", "with or having affection".
Expanded definition to include "well". For the moral sense of "good", see "Kul".
A compound of "Pruzah" and "Guur", a lengthier version of "Guur".
General term for any kind of bug or insect.
Derived from Pusojur and Nin to make Sting-bug.
Loosely based off of "Small" or "Pus" and "Truth" or "Vahzen".
Something one has a right to, something someone is entitled to obtain, or somehow they are entitled to act.
Part of the "Dragon aspect" shout in Dragonborn Dlc.
A compound of "Qahd" meaning "Chest" and "Tus" meaning "Plate." Armor someone would wear to cover the front of their torso.
Armor one would wear to cover the shoulders.
Literally "Bone-Ghost", Draugr is the Icelandic word for Ghost.
A compound meaning "bone-cold". Used as a verb. "Tol qethkrah", "that is spine-chilling".
Often used in reference to Word Walls. For the general word see "Golz".
Alleged "correct" spelling of "Quethsegolahrol", supposing that it was misspelled in the book "Holdings of Jarl Gjalund".
"Qiib" with the suffix "-iik," someone who is cute or adorable.
Means "to bow" rather than the weapon.
Lit. "bow-honor". Can also be used as a verb.
Part of the shout "Soul Cairn Summon", a shout only the dragon Durnehviir from Dawnguard dlc can use.

word.Definition: Granite Hill, was a small town in what was later Falkreath Hold
word.Notes: Possibly misspelled, may otherwise be "Qethsegolahrol": "stone hill"
As in a locked chest or "this lock is hard to pick", can also be used as a verb.
Based on words: Raf(Hole) and Rax(Tooth).
A compound that means "Godman". Plural is "Rahmuz", "Godmen".

word.Definition: Sanctuary, a sacred or holy place

word.Notes: The noun form of "Rahn", meaning "passage", "access", or "way", not a "passage/excerpt" from writing.
Based on the dovah words for god and disgrace/defile, "Rah" and "Kroved".
"Teeth" is included for search purposes. The plural form can either be "Rax" or "Raxxe".

word.Definition: Toothless, Spineless, can be used to refer to lack of dominance, strength, or courage
word.Notes: Can be used as a metaphor for "spineless"/ lacking dominance, strength, or courage.
This word has been inspired from Danish (redigere) and Swedish (redigera).
Sometimes a synonym to "Qo", "Reik" refers more to the magical element of shock and magical lightning.

word.Definition: Dominate, Rule, Ruler, Reign, Domination, Dominance
word.Notes: Expanded definition to include "rule," "ruler," "reign," domination," and "dominance."
Based on "Rel", "to dominate", "with or having dominance".
Literally, "rule of the crown." Edited from "Geinmu'ul."
To the extent, not also. See "Ahk."
A compound of "Revak" and "Iiz", it literally means "Sacred ice".
Of or relating to ceremony. Edited from "Revokoroniil."
Lit. "Anus gas". Can also be used as a noun.
"Reym" with suffix "-uv," lit. "of or pertaining to the anus."
Lit. "petly": used to describe something that is a pet; "aan rezus wor": "a pet walrus"

word.Definition: electro-, denotes relation to electricity, electric
word.Notes: Derived from "reik," "shock". "Rik-" is used if word begins with a vowel.
Comes from 'Ri-' and from 'gevoth' meaning 'Electric connection.'
The body part. Derived from Old Norse "hryggr". Can also be the preposition.
Part of the "Soul Tear" shout from the Dawnguard dlc.
Derived from "Rii", literally means "the essence of a situation".
Can mean a noun or a verb "to reek or smell", or "a reek or stench".
Can also be used as a verb "to clothe".
Derived from "Rik-", relating to electricity; "hah", mind; and "tus", plate.
Derived Risulor, "website," and "Pel", "to write". Fully, "electric thought write".
The bark of a tree, as opposed to a dog's bark.
"Qahd" with the modern prefix "Ri-," lit. "electronic chest."

word.Definition: Chatroom, phone-call, instant messaging, voice synthesis, any electronic means of communication

word.Notes: Based off the Finnish word "Riippuvainen". Shortened from "Riivun."
From "Ro" with the suffix "-aal", with or having balance.
Pronounced "rode". Derived from an old European root word for circle/round.
From the Icelandic for "drift," "reka." Edited from "Rakah." Can be used either as a noun or a verb.
Meaning to ready an arrow on a bow. Melding of "Ro", "balance", and "Ronaaz", "arrow."
Refers to a spoken or conceptual word, rather than a written word , which is "Sik".
Lit "word", "part". Can also be used as a verb.
From "Rot" and "Tun," "word-trade." The verb "to translate" and the noun "translation." Shortened from "Rotuun."
Derived from the words Rovahaan and Monah, it means Wanderlight Mother.
"Rukor" with the suffix "-uv", "of or pertaining to residue". Edited from "Rukoriil."
Special case, used only when the word is the first in the sentence.
Combination of "Rund" and the suffix "-ak". Shortened from "Rundak."
Chapter of a book or organization.
Primarily means "rage". Can also be used as an interjection, meaning "curses!" or "damn!"
Bolt of a crossbow, a small arrow. Can also be used as a verb, "to dart or bolt". Edited from "Stur".
Derived from the words Sah, Gah and Sagu (Old English, lit. "Say").
Variation of the dragon word for Mighty, Sahrot.
Refers to a group, rather than to dwell in thought.
From "Saanhah" and the suffix "-aal", "with or having dementia".
Can pertain to money or abundance of something; a rich land, or a rich color.
Altered to include British English spelling in the definition to make searching easier.
A compound of "Sahqo" and "Mun", "Redman". The plural is "Sahqomuz".
The verb "to excuse". See "Sahviir" for the noun.
Based on the Norwegian name for lettuce, salat.
The dragon name for "Cyrodiil", borrowed with alterations to spelling. Edited from "Siirodiil."
"Sarodaal" with the origin suffix "-en". This can mean the Cyrodiilic/English language, or anything from Cyrodiil. Edited from "Siirodiilen."
Derives from "Saviik", with the suffix "-iik" to modify it into "Savior".
Used rarely in sentence structure, mostly used in compound words.
From the words "Baas" and "Sed" meaning "art" and "three". To imply three works of art.
Meaning "light in weight", as opposed to visual light.
To mean something, rather than being mean/rude. Edited from suk to seik to avoid a homonym.
From "Sein," "slow," and "Raan," "animal." Refers only to the animal.
Can be used as a noun also.

word.Definition: Noobie, Newbie, Noob, Rookie, Recruit, a person who is inexperienced

word.Notes: Based on "kiir", "child". Used exclusively to refer to a child's toy.
More informal or casual than "Liis", which has more of a fierce or animalistic connotation.
Part of the "Battle Fury" shout in the Dragonborn dlc.

word.Definition: Handle, Manage, Manipulate, Operate, deal with

word.Notes: See also "Krein." A Word of Power. Possibly related to "Sul," "day." Connotations may be more strongly related to daylight, heat, and fire.
A combination of "Shul" and "Kun", edited from "Kreinhaan".
"Shul" suffixed with "-uv", "of or pertaining to the sun". Edited from "Kreiniil."
"Shun" with the suffix "-niir", "something you clean or wash with".
Lit. means "clean", "floor". Can also be used as a verb.
Derived from the composite Sizaan-Fahliil, it refers to the Falmer, as they exist post-enslavement. For Snow Elf, see "Odfahliil".
Old Norse corruption of "Sifjar" meaning "Affinity" as well.
Derived from "Sik" and "Golz" (by the analogy of "Dovahgolz")
With more benevolent connotations than "Gaaf" or "Hokzii".
From "Siigonis". Comhined with "Saak" to mean "Big Lizard".
Derived from Siin, Strin, and the Norwegian "Segl", meaning "Seal".
Extension of the word "Siin" (sign). Edited from "Siinda".
Derived from "Siin" (Sign). Verb "to signify or signal," and noun "signal or beacon."
A compound of "Find" or "Siiv", and "Truth" or "Vahzen".
Means a written word, not "Rot" which means more of a spoken word.
Literally, "soul frost." The opposite of the warmth in one's soul felt when one is in love.

word.Definition: mortal souls, the souls of mortals

word.Notes: Literal translation: Soul of the eye.
From "Kod", "wield". Not to be confused with the mechanical type of gear.
As in one reaps what one sows
See also "Sunvaar." Connotations may be more benign and nature-oriented, closer in meaning to "animal" than "monster."
From "Ag," "burn." To destroy, particularly by fire.
Can also be used as a verb "to taint".
From the words "Sken" meaning "Chain" and "Por" meaning "Island".
From "Niif" meaning "to smile." Also can be used as a noun.
To tilt. Derived from English word "skew".
Also can be used as a noun
From Icelandic. Can also be used as a noun.

word.Definition: Parlay, a cumulative series of bets

word.Notes: Lit. "flesh eater", based on the English etymology.
A compound meaning "flesh of the sky".
A compound of "Slen" or "Flesh" and "Blade" or "Tuz", literally means "flesh-blade".
"Slen" with the suffix "-uv," of or pertaining to the flesh and physical desire.
Like flesh, just more for edible purposes.
Can also be used as the noun. For the animal, see "Naat."
Refers to the sound made by horse's hooves.
Derived from Old Norse "sol" ("sun"). Only the color. For the fruit, see "Solfruk".
The metal "lead". See "Inaak" for the verb "to lead".
From "smahl", sheep, and "om", hair. Could also likely be generalized to refer to any type of wool (e.g. alpaca, etc).
Based on "som", "wool", but can refer to any yarn.
The word itself, as opposed to the prefix "So-".
Mixed of 3 different sounds: english "queer", german "seltsam" and russian "странный". Edited from "Senkjoor."
A compound of "Sos" and "Frin", it literally means "blood-hot" (on the analogy of "Sosdiin", "blood-freeze")
Reverse-derived from "Ensosin", "bewitch". Possibly a compound of "Sos" and "In", "blood-master". This has a more vile connotation than "Lahbriin".
From "Sosin" and using "Kroson," "work," as a partial suffix to make "works or deeds of a witch."
"Sosin" with "-maar," "witchhood." Could also be seen as "witch-terror."
Based on words: Sos(Blood) and Kostim(Spider).
Derived from "Sos" and "Strah", it means literally "blood's way". Can be used to mean either a vein or an artery.
Sot: white, Laakir: leek. Derived from the base Scandinavian "vit-lok" ("garlic", literally, "white leek").
As in, a plane of existence.
"Sov" with the suffix "-aht", "that which is spent".
The dragon language does not have a separate name for Sovngarde.
Also the noun "shelter/safeguard". "Spaan" should be used over this in cases where the direct translation is "shield".
From "Spaan," "shield." Also usable as a verb, "to protect or shield as with a screen."
The noun meaning "a place", as opposed to the verb "Raal" which means "to place or put". Added to the definition to clear confusion between it and "Raal".

word.Definition: Longshoreman, Docker, someone who loads and unloads ships at port

word.Notes: Longing for someone/something that is absent, not to miss a target.
A bail of hay, rather than the monetary sense.
A magic spell, not the verb "to spell".

word.Definition: to cast or use a spell

word.Notes: Can be a verb or a noun.
Based on steg (to step), "that which is stepped."
The noun meaning "quietness/stillness", not an adjective.
"Stiild" with the suffix "-us" to form an adjective.
Refers to a sink of water, etc., not the verb meaning "to sink". Edited from "Styorn" and "Stjorn."
A basic principle or item; "a staple of the fantasy genre," not referring to the "stapler" tool.
To blink your eyes. Strin: shut, Miin: eyes. Edited from "Srinmiin".
The verb meaning "to close", not the adjective meaning "close" or "near". Edited from "Srin".
Combination of "Strun" and the suffix "-us". Mainly means "stormy" but can also mean "angry".
From "Stum" with the suffix "-en". Edited from "Sedinen."
Inspired from the Old english word "styrian".
From "Fask", "delicate". Meaning "something delicate". Also used as a noun.
From "Sufol" and "Du'ul", "sugar-crown". Can also be a verb "to coat/crown with sugar".
Derived from "Suk", "least". Also used as an adjective.
For both noun and verb -- to comfort someone, or to find comfort in something.) Edited from "Suhlvek".
The verb form of "Su'um", also derived from "Su".
Refers to "Sum", is its own plural.
See also "Sivaas." Connotations may be more wild or savage, closer in meaning to "monster" than "animal."
Derived from "Sos", with the suffix "-us", contracted to form an easier-to-pronounce word.
The verb meaning "to figure", rather than a person "figure".
Refers to a pack of animals.
Imitative of the dental click sound.

word.Definition: Glutton, Gorger, Gobbler, one who eats excessively

word.Notes: From the words "Tegal" meaning "counter" and the word "Rot" meaning "word".
From the word "Tegalrot" meaning "Object" and the suffix "-ak".

word.Definition: Add, Augment, Increase, Produce, Amplify, make many of

word.Notes: This refers to the power of the Voice, not regular speech.
A slur or curse, implying someone is incapable of the Voice.
From "Thun" and "Uth," someone who commands law.
"Thun" with the suffix "-uv", "of or pertaining to the law". Edited from "Thuniil."
An adjective that means "lawless", as well as a noun that means "bandit" or "outlaw".
A compound meaning "overlord word". The adjective "absolute" and a noun meaning "an absolute truth".
Altered from "Tuuz" to avoid homophone with "Tuz". Edited from "Tuus" to avoid homophone with "Tus."
To count time or items. Like "Krii", its past form is "Tiaan".

word.Definition: time-flight, time travel, also as a verb, to fly through time
Existing outside of time, or not bound to the laws of time
word.Notes: Primarily in reference to the Elder Scrolls. Lit. "time-unbound." Edited from "Miirney."

word.Definition: Flashback, Recollection, thoughts of the past
Talk, Speak, Discuss / Speech, Conversation, Discussion
word.Notes: Can be used as both a verb, "to talk/speak", and a noun meaning "talk", "speech", or "conversation".
Lit. "out of time", or "out of the finite time".
"Tokaas" with the suffix "-iik," "that which does math."
From "Tolaak," "to twist," with the suffix "-niir." "That which is twisted."
A compound of "Kranek" and "Ton". Extended from "Tonkraan."
Can also be used as a verb, "to err, mistake, error, fault".

word.Definition: Caravan, Train, any procession of travelers

word.Notes: Edited from "Wernek". Means "of or originating from the tropics".
From "Tum," "down." The verb "to sink," not the noun.
A compound of "Trum" (sink) and "Gol" (earth). Edited from "Styorngol."
Used to mean both "still" and "yet." From "Rul," "when." Edited from "Maht."
Based on "Wuld," "whirlwind," in a sense of spinning.
From "Tum" and "Mah". Also a verb, "to collapse, crumble, or have a downfall."
From the words "Tum" meaning "Down" and "Bo" meaning "Move".

Related to "Hahkun". This type of axe is sometimes called a Wagoner’s Axe. It is known that axes of this type were carried with the wagon trains supporting medieval and Renaissance armies. It was probably used as both a tool and a weapon and many are found in various armories around the world.

word.Definition: Race, Sprint, to move at full speed

word.Notes: Based of the Norwegian word "oppfinnelse". Edited from "Ufiinseh".
Can be used as a noun or a verb.
Based on "Aal". The verb "might", not the noun meaning "strength/power".
Can also be used as a verb, "to log/record".
Can be used as a noun or a verb.
Edited to "Unad" so it doesn't conflict with the verb suffix "-iin".
"Unad" with "-aan". Is also the present perfect form of "Unad", "have chosen".

word.Definition: Unending / Ceaseless / Eternal (less common than Unslaad)

word.Notes: From the words "Tiid" meaning "Time" and "Unad" meaning "Choose".
Related to "Unslaad", "unending". Can be used as an adjective or an adverb.
"Unt" with the suffix "-ak", the act of trying.
derived from German “Uhr“ and from Latin “hōra“ (“hour”)
Can also be used as a noun.
Based on the Norwegian and Finnish language.
Lit. "before the present time". This word previously meant "past".
From Us "before" and Ris "to place". Can also be used as a pronoun.
Edited from "Jovein". Means "not bound to the world".
Rare version of "Unslaad". Only occurs once. Alternate or possibly incorrect spelling of "Uznahgaar."
From Uznahgaar 'unbridled,' Vis 'can,' and Nos 'to strike.'
Related to "Gol", "earth", "sturdy or stout as earth".
"To keep at bay", "to hold at bay", rather than the body of water.
Can be also used as a verb
From the "Soul Tear" shout in the Dawnguard dlc. Tear rip, not Tear cry.
Derived from "Vahlok" and "Golz" (by the analogy of "Dovahgolz").
From "Vah", "spring", and "Lomok", "pool", refers to a water or mineral spring.
The direction left, as opposed to the past tense of leave.
Based on the word "Vahden" which means maiden.
"Vah" with the suffix "-nuv", "of or pertaining to spring". Edited from "Vahiil.
From "Vo-Ahraan," "un-wound." The verb "to heal" and the noun "healing/treatment." Edited from "Tolsek."

word.Definition: Healer, any kind of healer or treater of wounds, mental, physical, or otherwise
word.Notes: From "Vahraan" with the suffix "-iik." Edited from "Tolsekiin."

word.Definition: A person who maintains strict discipline or rule, Martinet

word.Notes: A geographic coast, rather than the verb "to coast (along)".
Shortened variation of "Vakron" with the -om suffix.
The noun form of "Valk", "Nervous", with the suffix "-om".
An alternate form of "Vax" with the suffix "kei".
"Veik" with the suffix "-us", "having the qualities of acid".
Similar to "Yal" but refers more to an object that is thin, whereas "Yal" refers more to an opening, passage, or space that is thin.
Primarily means "wind." Expanded definition to also mean "path" or "way".

word.Definition: Style, Manner, Method, Fashion, Technique, Demeanor

word.Notes: "Make [noun]", the act of creating the noun applied. Verdrem; to make peace. Verkein; to make war.
"Bahs" with the prefix "Ver-" and the suffix "-iik", "someone who makes art". Literally, "artmaker". Edited from "Verbahsiik".

word.Definition: Strive, Endeavor, Focus, to make an effort
word.Notes: "Grav" with the prefix "Ver-", "to make an effort".

word.Definition: Paint, Draw, to make a picture
word.Notes: A non-specific term for a method of creating an image.
A compound of "Verin" and "Rii", "Element essence". Refers to ethereal spirits of elements (for example, Ice Wraith - "Iizinrii" - elemental of ice and snow)
"Kein" with the prefix "Ver-" and the suffix "-iik", lit. "someone who makes war".
As opposed to Liin (mate/sex) which doesn't necessarily have the purpose of breeding. Ver: to make, Kiir: child

word.Definition: Play, Perform, music-making, to perform or play a song
word.Notes: "Lovaas" with the prefix "Ver-," "to make music." Should be used as an intransitive verb; "Rek verlovaas," "she is making music."
"Lovaas" with the prefix "Ver-" and suffix "-niir", fully meaning "something one makes music with".
Lit. "to make a report or account".
"Rut" with the prefix "Ver-", "to make danger or threats towards". Edited from "Verhask."
The verb from "Visk", lit. "to make celebration".

This word was created using the Icelandic word for "scene", "vettvangur." In a happy accident, the Dovahzul word "vet" means "to hone or file," which works, since a scene is a honed or concentrated section of an act (as in a play).
From "Veydo" and "Raak," lit. "grass-stick" or "weed-stick", Shortened for phonetic reasons.
From "Veydo" and "Pusaas," lit. "grass-powder" or "weed-powder", Shortened for phonetic reasons.

A compound of "Vey","Se" and "Nor", it literally means "cut of land". Solstheim was a part of mainland, but it was sundered from the rest of Skyrim as a result of the battle between Dragon Priests Vahlok and Miraak.
Ment to sound similar to bizaar
"Viid" with the suffix "-en", "originating or of water".
The directional right, as opposed to just/fair or correct. Edited from "Volt."

word.Definition: Shimmer, Glimmer, Glisten, Sparkle, Glow, Glint

word.Notes: Derived from the composition of the words Vith and Muz, its literal meaning is Serpent-Men and refers to the serpent-folk of Akavir.
"Viing" with the suffix "-aal", "with or having wings".
As a verb, "to die or cease."
Based on the Finnish word "Viiru" for "streak".
From "Viik," "defeat." The verb "to damn" and the noun "damnation." Preferably pronounced with a short "i."
From Old English word for twitch; 'Twiccan'.
Edited from "Lokaaltok". From "Lokaal" and "Vis", "can be loved".
Has influences from ancient norse word for accomplish, which is "vinna".
"Nix" and "Vuld" along with the prefix "Vi-" to make "able of being swapped between" or "interchangeable".
Edited from "Piintok". From "Piin" and "Vis", "can be drunk".
Derived from "Rot". Can also be used as a verb.
Edited from "Aagistok". From "Aagis" and "Vis", "can be erased".
A compound of "Eim" and "Vis", "can accept". Edited from "Eimtok".
Edited from "Gezeydahtok". From "Vis" and "Gezeydah", "can be justified".
"Korah" combined with "Vis", "can be believed". Edited from "Korahtok".
Edited from "Krahltok" and "Vismaal." From "Tolaan," "to desire," with "Vis," "can be desired."

word.Definition: Un- prefix. (opposite of. e.g. unkind, unlikeable)

word.Notes: "Balaan" with the prefix "Vo-". Changed from incorrect "Vobahlaan."
From the word "Bavir" meaning "Couth" with the prefix "Vo-".

word.Definition: Flak, could be used for any anti-air weapon
Unearth, Exhume, Excavate, to dig up

word.Notes: "Digol" with the prefix "Vo-", lit. "to make something not a mystery".
Combination of the prefix Vo- and Diin, lit. "unfreeze".
A mutation of "Drem", "peace", with the prefix "Vo-". Edited from "Vodren."
"Vodrem" with "Vulz," "disturbed pulse" or "to disturb a pulse."
"Fir" with prefix "Vo-". Can also be used as a noun.
Derived from "Vofrul" and "Aar", "permanent-servant", referring to the Conjuration spells. Edited from "Ahgulaar."
"Gahvon" with the prefix "Vo-", literally "un-yield". Edited from "Vogah".
From "Genun" with the prefix "Vo-." Edited from "Vodahvur."
A combination of "Unaz" with the prefix "Vo".
A literal combination of "Vok" and "nau". A contracted version of this word is "Von".
Lit. "un-break." Edited from "Zifahl." Also a noun.
From "Vokrii", "to revive". Also "Kriid" with the prefix "Vo-".
"Vokrii" combined with the suffix "-nd". Edited from "Yahnd" to match canon.
Opposite of "Bolaav", "to grant". Is the verb "to refuse or reject" and the noun "refusal or rejection".
From "Lahvraan" with the prefix "Vo-," "ungather." Edited from "Eyfur."
"Volbur" with the suffix "-aal", "with or having chaos, change, disorder".
Lit. "un-world," refers to any realm outside of Mundus.
Volg + Nor, wildlands Edited from "Feykrovolg" since "wilderness" can refer to more than just forest.
A harsh-sounding, definitive word. Can also be used as a verb.

word.Definition: Dam, Obstruction, can refer to anything that holds something back

word.Notes: A place in Skyrim, named the same in the Dragon Tongue as English.
Edited from "Vol" to "Volz" to avoid conflict with the canon "Vol".
Derived from Volz: worse. Structured following Pruzah, Pruz, Pruzaan (good, better, best). Edited from "Volah" to avoid conflict with the canon "Vol".
A contraction of "Vok" and "Nau", more casual and conversational than "Voknau".
Also an adjective, from "Ov" with the prefix "Vo".
Literally "non rare", Vo-: non, Num: rare, edited from "vonun".
"Vonum" with the suffix "-iik," someone who is common.
From "Vonun," "unseen." Also a noun. Edited from "Suuvan."
From "Vorpaal", "different". Can also used be used as a verb.
From "Rivun" with the prefix "Vo-" and the suffix "-aal," "not having dependence."
Vo + orlaav. Can also be used as noun.
Combines the first part of "different" and the word "sexual"
Edited from "Hren". The adjective "mad or insane", and the noun "madness or insanity". Means "unbalanced-mind / unbalanced-minded".
Can also be used as an adjective, "organized".
From the Icelandic for "past," "fortíð." Replaces the former word "On".
Compound of "Vortii" and "Lok", "beyond-skies" as a metaphor for being beyond normal.
Edited from "Tok". Related to "Vis", "can." The adjective "able," and now also the verb "to enable / allow / let"
From "Sav", "Save" with prefix "Vo-". Not to be confused with the imperative meaning "don't save."
Based on the root word "Vos". Edited from "Tokmaar".
Compound of "Vos" and "Mah," "to let fall." Edited from "Ilmah."

word.Definition: Misdeed, Transgression, Sin, Vice, Crime, Wrongdoing
word.Notes: "Sod," "deed," with the prefix "Vo-." Refers to any act of wrongdoing; illegal, immoral, traitorous, or disobedient.
