Edited from "Wultriin." Refers to a person who has committed any act of wrongdoing.
"Sotiiv" with the prefix "vo-," lit. "unexcite." Edited from "Zaknah."
Edited from "Nost" to avoid conflict with the name "Lodunost."
A combination of "Voth" with the suffix "-ni".
"Ativut" with the prefix "Vo-". To move backward or away.
From "Votivut" with the suffix "-aal," having recession or being prone to recede.
"Vozah" with the suffix "-rom". There is already a word for "infinity", "Mintiinon", but this is derived from primary canon along with our "-rom" suffix (to form a noun from an adjective).
From "Vrii" with the suffix "-iid", "something that has scales".
Can also be used as a verb. Shortened from "Vuug."

word.Definition: Shift, Change, Modify, Mutate, Transfer, Transform, Transmute

word.Notes: The adjective rather than the Daedric Prince. A combination of "Laas" and "Vulon".
"Vulzid" with the suffix "-en", meaning "from an abyss". Edited from "Fruunen".
From Bethesda's old word for "voice", related to "Zun", "weapon".
Can be used as a verb, "to pickpocket".
Edited from "Dahv" and "Todaas." Related to "Haalvut," "to touch."
From the "Battle Fury" shout in the Dragonborn dlc.
Based on "Vis", "can". Edited from "Vus" to avoid conflict with the canon word "Vus", "Nirn".
Inspired from the Old English word "weorð".
The verb meaning "to block/obstruct" or the equivalent noun, not something "block-shaped", or "to shape something like a block".
"Wah" can be used as both a preposition and to make infinitive verbs ("to wander", " to fight", etc.).
Used to describe the creation of something. For the sense of "to cause something to become," as in "to make happy," see "Mur."
Edited from "Wahlaat," added other definitions to canon "Wahlaan," "creation."
Meaning "of, like, or pertaining to fantasy". Edited from "Wahrasiil."
Also a verb, "to haul or to load".
To wage war, rather than a worker's wage.
The tool, not the past tense form of "to see". Also can be used as a verb.
Lit. means "Vortex/whirlwind of time". Related to "Vennesetiid", "winds of time", but with a more wild or chaotic connotation.
Derives from "Wundun" ("travel"), implying that a "traveler" is seeking their "quest" or "purpose".
Refers to the act of bathing, and the place in which one bathes.
Derived from "Wuth", "Rah", and the suffix "-nuv", "of old gods". Edited from "Wuthrahiil."
Similar to "Veirey" but refers more to an opening, passage, or space that is thin. "Veirey" refers to an object that is thin.
A compound of "Yal" and "Zahkrii",literally means "narrow sword".
The verb meaning "to call or hail", rather than the precipitation. Related to "Rein," "roar." Edited from "Hein."
Can also be used as a verb, "to arm".
Can also be used as a verb, "to torch".
A compound of "Yol" and "Angaar", "fire tower". Edited from "Yolangar".
A compound of "Yol" and "Lein", "fire of the world". Can mean both the verb "to erupt" and the noun "eruption".
Derived from primary canon "Yol" and partially quarternary canon "Gosvaa".
Connected to the word "Yol" ("fire"), something "rising from the ashes".
Lit. means "fire", "grain". Not to be confused with a drinking straw.

Composed by the words Yol and Strunmah, it literally means Fire-Mountain and refers to the most obvious element of a vulcano. Alternately, a vulcano can also be called a Dovastrun or Dovahstrunmah, referring to the shared trait - fire.
Derived of the words "Yolstrunmah" and "Nor", it literally means "Land of the Volcano"
Shortened version of "Yolostaas". Not to be confused for "firing".
Related to "Trin". As in a fuse for a bomb or cannon. Not to be confused with "Hilk".
Literally "Fire Spirit". A bright, driving, motivating passion, usually constructive. See also "Agzii" and "Frinzii"
From the words "Yol" meaning "Fire" and "Zoor" meaning "Legend".
Derived from Yol, meaning fire and Su meaning air. Edited to "Yos" to prevent a vowel ending.
Lit. means "heat", "wind". Can also be used as a noun.
A generic word for any kind of money or currency. From "Yuvon", "gold".
A combination of Yuld, gold, and Mey, fool.
From "Yun", a person or thing that is new. Edited from "Yoriin".
Lit. "new-hatch." Only refers to lizards or other creatures, cannot be used to refer to dragons in any sense.
To Bake, "Yosnol" comes from "Yos" and "Yahnol" wich mean "Heat" and "cooking" To make it more distinguishable from "Yahnol", the "O" from "Yos" became an "U".
From the shout "Soul Cairn Summon", a shout only the dragon Durnehviir Can use in the Dawnguard Dlc.
This refers to actual speech, not the Voice.
Particularly as said of a vista, scene, etc., especially an admirable one.
Derived from the words Dez and Gah, based on the words Ende and Gad (Old-English, lit. meaning "point").
Somewhat based on Zahkrii (Sword), Horns are sharp a large majority of the time.

word.Definition: dragon priest name, lit. "sword-blood," bloodied sword

word.Notes: A small knife at the end of a rifle used for stabbing.
"Zahraan" with the suffix "-om". Edited from "Zegranom" and "Zahgraanom."
The "a" is emphasized. Prounounciation may vary with dialect, of course.
This is based on the elven word for misery from the Inheritance Cycle book series.
"Zent" with the suffix "-aal", "with or having expectations".
The accusative and dative case of "Zu'u".
Just or morally right. For the adverb, see "Nunon". Edited from "Zeyda".
A modification of the word "Zeymah" based on "Briinahmaar", "sisterhood". Altered from "Zeymahdein" to align more with canon.
Combination of "Silver" and "Gold", just like electrum.
"Zin" with the suffix "-aal", "with or having honor".
Can be used as both a noun and a verb.

The prefix is used to modify a noun to an adjective, and is equivalent to the English "-ful", seen in "fearful" and "joyful", and the Dragon "Zofaas" and "Zojiik". This isn't always the case, however ("Brii" is "beauty" and "Brit" is "beautiful"). It is also seen in "Zohungaar", "heroically".
A combination of "Drem" with the prefix "Zo-".
The put-together combination of grace and -ful.
Based on "Ofan", "to give", with the prefix "Zo-", "full of giving".
"Grit" with the prefix "Zo-", means "with or full of doubt". Edited from "Zoren."
"Zugut" with the suffix "-iik", "someone who is extreme".
From "Haas" with the prefix "zo-," "full of health."
Used as a prefix, this is equivalent to the English "-est", in "fastest", "bravest", etc.
"Keyr" with the prefix "Zo-". Much different connotation than English's meaning of "cool". "Zokeyr" implies being grand or awe-striking.
Derived from "Zok", "most". Can be used as an noun and an adverb.
"Krosis" with the prefix "Zo-." Used as the adjective "sorry," "a sorry affair."
Can be both noun and verb
"Maar" with the prefix "Zo-", something "full of terror".
From "Zoor" with the suffix "-uv". Edited from "Zooriil."
"Paak" with the suffix "Zo-," full of shame.
"Paar" with the prefix "Zo-", literally "full of ambition".
From "Aax" with the prefix "Zo-." Edited from "Zoarx."
Edited from "Gremak." "Vodrem" with the prefix "Zo-," "full of violence."
"Ko" with the prefix "Zu-". Used for inanimate objects; "an inner edge." See also "Kosil."
Lit. means "more", "necessary". Means exceeding what is necessary or natural.
The actual mortal voice, not the power of Shouting ("Thu'um").
Both the verb "to communicate" and the noun "communication." Edited from "Kiilaar." Means "to voice with."
To board a ship, rather than a wooden board.
Derived from zurun with the suffix -iik.
Can also be used as a noun.
"Wuth" combined with the prefix "Zu-". Can also be used as a noun.
